bibl.title: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Henry Rose Carter, February 6, 1924

div1.p: Russell writes about field work in Brazil and suggests a possible yellow fever re-infection of Africa by way of Brazil. He encloses a documents from Strode concerning yellow fever, and refers to a letter from White [noted by Russell as enclosed but not with this group of documents.]

February 6, 1924.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have received the letters of January thirti-
eth and February second from Miss Laura and the enclosed
manuscript of Section II. Thank you ever so much for
sending the manuscript to me at this time.

Our yellow fever news is, as you know, all
good. Yesterday we received a letter from Doctor White,
dated January eighth, copy of which I am enclosing for
your information. You will notice in the last paragraph
of his letter he says that he is beginning to suspect
that Bahia is the place that re-infected Africa which is
only four days away. I am looking up as far as possible
the steamship communications between Bahia and West Africa.
There is a French line, the Sud Atlantique, which has
three ships that make the trip once a month in seven or
eight days. I have written Doctor White asking him for
sailing dates to West Africa from Bahia; he will probably

O Bido

I hope that you are arranging your work so that
it will not take all your energy. Leave a little over to
enjoy other things!

Yours very sincerely, F. F. Russell
P.S. I am also enclosing copy of a
